lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six job roles (fly planes, take care of teeth, take pictures, deliver letters, repair cars, design buildings) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Match job titles with job roles on the board: “fly planes – pilot”. Students match SB images to actions through a simple matching line task.
stretchStrategies: Students work in pairs to make a mini “Jobs & Roles Poster.” They draw or choose two jobs and write what they do (e.g., “Dentists take care of teeth.”). Then share with the class.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about job roles using “What do (job plural) do?” and respond with “They...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Group quiz: Show a job (e.g., architect). Ask: “What do architects do?” Group says: “They design buildings.” Rotate roles quickly.
stretchStrategies: Students work in pairs to make a mini “Jobs & Roles Poster.” They draw or choose two jobs and write what they do (e.g., “Dentists take care of teeth.”). Then share with the class.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “What do ___ do?” / “They ___.” to talk about job roles.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Display “What do ___ do? – They ___.” on board. Students fill in a mini worksheet using job roles and job names from SB.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
